bibl.title: Letter from Mabel H. Lazear to George A. Kellogg, August 7, 1941

div1.p: Mabel Lazear expresses her approval of Cornwell's painting, "Conquerors of Yellow Fever," and requests more copies. She mentions her preoccupation with war preparations.

div1.head: Letter from Mabel H. Lazear to George A. Kellogg, August 7, 1941
div1.opener:
C O P Y
116 East Padre Street
Santa Barbara, California
August 7, 1941
George A. Kellogg, Esq.
257 Cornelison Avenue
Jersey City, New Jersey
My dear Mr. Kellogg
div1.p:
Your letter of July 14 and the photograph of the
painting “conquerors of Yellow Fever” arrived duly and
deserved a prompter acknowledgment. My excuse is the war-
being very busy with the Committee of Defend America, in
this city. I therefore hope you will forgive me and ac-
cept my belated but none the less sincere thanks.

One of our leading physicians here, Dr. Franklin
R. Nozum, who attended the Convention of Doctors in Cleve-
land and saw the painting, was so enthusiastic over it that
he told me all about it, and I was therefore not altogether
surprised when I received the excellent photograph of the
painting. No words can fully express my gratitude to you
for sending me also the clippings which were so helpful in
making the picture interesting in detail. So far as I knew
these physicians through my husband and pictures I had seen
of them, they appear to me to be very good likenesses, and
I can only add that the artist has brought a feeling of en-
thusiasm, sincereity and realism to it which is communicative
of the spirit which animated the entire commission. I hope
you will convey for me to Mr. Dean Cornwell the feeling that
I have expressed of his triumph.

I should like to add to my own appreciation that of
my son and daughter who, I know, would treasure photographs
of the painting and I hope it will not be asking too much to
request seven copies.

Again, with my heartfelt thanks for all the minute
trouble you have taken in this matter, I am.
